item.title: Research
item.description:
My research experience spans topics in environmental and development economics, neighborhood dynamics, poverty, and forced migration. Across these roles, I have supported faculty and supervisors alike through data cleaning, analysis, and visualization of results for presentations and publications using Stata, R, and ArcGIS Pro, often working with large administrative datasets and spatial data.

Research Experience

  • Research Assistant, Dr. Anna Maria Santiago, Michigan State University, 2022–present
    Conduct data analysis and spatial modeling on poverty, neighborhood effects, and low-income homeownership using Stata, R, and ArcGIS Pro. Contributed to one published article and several co-authored manuscripts under review, while also gaining experience with large-scale national housing datasets.

item.title: Teaching
item.description:
Teaching is one of the most meaningful parts of my academic life. I love helping students engage with complex ideas, develop confidence in their own thinking, and see the relevance of economics in the world around them.

Certificate in College Teaching

  • Completed interdisciplinary pedagogy training through MSU’s Graduate School program.
  • Designed and implemented a mentored teaching project (FAST Fellowship) exploring how cooperative learning and generative AI can strengthen analytical reasoning in economics education.
  • Developed a student-centered, evidence-based teaching philosophy that emphasizes inclusivity, relatability, and critical thinking.

Teaching Experience

  • Teaching Assistant, EC 302: Intermediate Microeconomics, Michigan State University, Spring 2021
  • Teaching Assistant / Guest Lecturer, EC 202: Introduction to Macroeconomics, Michigan State University, Fall 2021
  • Teaching Assistant, EC 301: Intermediate Microeconomics, Michigan State University, 2019–2020 (2 semesters)

Information for (potential) advisees

This is a note for Harvard PhD students who would like me to advise their reseach. Importantly, none of the following is set in stone. Different types of advising relationships work best for different students. If you would like me to be your advisor, come talk to me, and we can discuss what would work best for you.

I am a PhD Candidate in Environmental, Urban, and Applied Microeconomics at Michigan State University.

My research focuses on how mandatory flood risk disclosure laws for rental properties affect rental housing markets, rent prices, and sorting patterns.

My dissertation examines these dynamics in two U.S. states, Indiana and Texas, leveraging proprietary housing data, geospatial risk information, and natural experiments around policy implementation.

More broadly, I am interested in the growing reliance on rental housing, climate adaptation, and the role of real estate markets in shaping household exposure to natural hazards. My work explores how people respond to new information, the extent to which they value it, and how state and federal policies can both support adaptation and potentially reinforce existing inequities.
